facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave against the order of the High Court of Kerala dated August 2, 1963, in Income-tax Reference Case No. 48/62 Agricultural.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal, by special leave, against the order of the High Court of Kerala dated August 2, 1963, in Income- tax Reference Case No. 48/62  Agricultural . The facts leading to this appeal may be briefly stated.

facts.text: The respondent is a company which owned a rubber estate purchased by it along with the plantation thereon.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to this appeal may be briefly stated. The respondent is a companypany which owned a rubber estate purchased by it along with the plantation thereon.

facts.text: The estate included rubber trees which, at the time of purchase, were in a condition of producing latex.

anchor.surface_text: The estate included rubber trees which, at the time of purchase, were in a companydition of producing latex. The rubber trees were sold by the companypany after they ceased to yield latex any further.

anchor.surface_text: the Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, by his order dated February 2, 1962, included the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees which were cut down and sold after they became useless. facts.text: Respondent appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales Tax, Quilon, objecting to inclusion of the amount in computing agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales Tax, Quilon, objecting, inter alia, to the inclusion of the amount in companyputing its agricultural income. By order dated November 30, 1960, the Deputy Commissioner rejected the companytention of the respondent.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner by order dated November 30, 1960 rejected the contention of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated November 30, 1960, the Deputy Commissioner rejected the companytention of the respondent. The respondent thereupon preferred a second appeal to the Agricultural Income-tax Appellate, Tribunal, Trivandrum.

facts.text: Respondent preferred second appeal to Agricultural Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Trivandrum.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon preferred a second appeal to the Agricultural Income-tax Appellate, Tribunal, Trivandrum. By its order dated August 18, 1962, the Tribunal accepted the companytention of the respondent

facts.text: Tribunal by order dated August 18, 1962 accepted respondent's contention and held Rs. 8,532.50 sale proceeds of rubber trees capital receipt not taxable as income.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated August 18, 1962, the Tribunal accepted the companytention of the respondent and held that the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees cut down and sold after they had become useless was number taxable as income, but was merely a capital receipt.

facts.text: On application of appellant, Tribunal stated case to Kerala High Court and referred two questions of law.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the appellant, the Tribunal stated a case to the Kerala High Court and referred the following two question of law for its opinion Whether the sale proceeds of old and unlying rubber trees grown and used for obtaining income as latex therefrom are capital receipts ?

facts.text: High Court Division Bench by judgment dated August 2, 1963 answered the two questions in the affirmative in favour of respondent.

This is an appeal, by special leave, against the order of the High Court of Kerala dated August 2, 1963, in Income-tax Reference Case No. 48/62 Agricultural.

The appellant thereupon obtained special leave to appeal to this court. The appellants contention mainly is that the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 was in the nature of a revenue receipt and had to be included in computing the agricultural income.

for the purposes of the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950  XXII of 1950 , the Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, by his order dated February 2, 1962, included the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees which were cut down and sold after they became useless.

anchor.surface_text: Now, section 2 a  of the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950  XXII of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act, defines agricultural income. Agricultural income means -  1  any rent or revenue derived from land which is used for agricultural purposes

concepts.interpretation: The definition does not include proceeds from the sale of rubber trees utilised for deriving income in the shape of latex

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the respondent did number grow the rubber trees for the purpose of selling them. It was getting income from these rubber trees in the shape of latex. In course of time the rubber trees became old and unyielding. When the trees were numberlonger productive of latex, the respondent felled them and sold them. The Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were, therefore, rights in holding that the sale proceeds of these trees should be treated as capital receipt and number taxable as agricultural income.
